text: Hello everyone
I'm surprised to find so many here
I'm trying to install Ubuntu on an Old World PowerBook
wow, you're hardcore
hang on a minute
When I'm initially installing ubuntu (repartitioning and all that), how do I select the most minimal installation/
choose the server install
Which is the server install?
Can I install server using BootX/
should be just like the warty
all the things you did with warty will need to be done here
I don't understand where I'm supposed to enter 'server'
at the boot, it should say 'press f1 for help or <enter> to boot'
press f1 and look for what to type for a server install
There is no server option that I can find
i'm very unfamiliar with the boot sequence
i wish i had a mac i could boot up with the disk to walk you through
Thanks.  I have a number of obstacles, but I have faith, with the help of this helpful support crew here, that I'll get this system up and running the way I want it.
in a couple of days, i can walk you through the procedure (i'm fixin to get new mac, and will be installing ubuntu on it)
I'm using a very old Mac, so I don't know if you'll encounter the same issues.
have faith, i know much voodoo (just cant remember which button to push at the boot prompt)
No worries, I'll get this up and running with yours (and others) help.  I have a feeling this next method is going to work, apt-get upgrade-dist from Warty to Hoary.
you can dump the xserver and all the gui packages
I'm writing that down, xserver and gui packages.  Which are the GUI packages, besides xserver-xfree86?
gtk stuff
I wanted an iBook for so long; finally found this old PowerBook at...well, nalioth knows where!
they don't have to
a BRAND new ibook can be had for $999
and refurbished (with full factory warranty) ibooks can be had for $799
I just bought a PowerBook for $60 (as you know) - oh yeah, and a sh*tload of hassle!
no hassle at all...CHALLENGE
Right, right, *challenge*, sure, sure.
makes you a better person, AND think of what you'll be able to pass on in here
Yes, when I get her runnin' properly.
I have faith.
Take it easy
sounds to me like you've dont it
you done it, now ya just gotta configure your bootx
Got it
Let's hope that's it.  This type of upgrade upgrades the kernel, too doesn't it?  It looks to be the same name/version, though.
you will need to move your kernel and the other thing so taht bootx can find them
Okay.  Yeah, I've been doing that with every reboot after an apt-get upgrade.
Back in awhile, hopefully
not kdm?
Hello, dude!
Or lady
I didn't like gnome on this old Mac, so I apt-get install fluxbox and then apt-get install wdm
How are you today?
sounds good
i'm fine, and you?
Good.  Which display manager do you use?
the default gdm runs underneath my gnome
I finally got my first view of gnome yesterday.
and already tired of it? lol
It was dog slow on this old Mac.
thought flux was a display mangler?
Is it?  Sheesh, I've got alot to learn.
A mangler?
LOL
HaroldJohnson sorry, i meant desktop manager (like kde or gnome)
i'm not much into GUIs, so 'file manglers, desktop manglers, window manglers, etc'
do you get a graphical login screen?
I finally did today.
ok then, at that screen, click 'sessions' and choose xfce4
I logged in but received an error saying the session lasted only 10 seconds because of blah blah blah.
that has nothing to do wiht xfce4
Okay, thanks, I'll try that.
I'm going now to try.
you might like to read this http://linuz.sns.it/~max/twin/
Looks like I got that error again.
at a failsafe terminal in your homedir, type 'rm .ICEauthority'
and then try to log back in to xfce
What is that removing, and why?
the .ICEauthority file is supposed to be read/write, but sometines it gets 'locked' by unknowing processes
Okay, I'll try that
You're a star.  But there's a problem; when I log into xfce, there's a little silouette of a mouse in the middle of the screen.
thats the mascot, don't worry, it doesnt eat much
LOL
I'm going to try using it, now.
It's a *really* satisfying feeling to finally see a desktop on this old bird...
xfce may be too much for 64MB to handle; I may have to switch to fluxbox.
congratulations (and what a wiki i can see coming out of your experience)
you could also try matchbox
I'll take you up on that (the wiki).
I dig Ubuntu's color scheme.
you might want to give matchbox a try, it is lighter than fluxbox
What's lighter, fluxbox or xfce?
flux
Okay, I'm going to play with xfce for awhile now.
I just sent first email using Ubuntu.  It was a Gmail.  I'm so excited!
Once Firefox finally loaded up, it's running good on xfce so far.
you might want to run kazehakaze (it uses the gecko engine, but is a bit lighter running)
I'll write that down for later.
I actually have preferred the plain-jane Mozilla to Firefox, though Firefox is gorgeous.
I feel like Charlie in the Chocolate Factory right now.
great!
Okay, I'm going to go back to playing with it, then I've got to figure out how to set up my D-Link pcmcia card for wireless browsing.
every day a new mountaintop, with a view to the next higher peak
Well, it's been fun.  I'm going back to OS X now.
what? on the pb?
I'm just kidding.
i'm surprised you got osx goin on the old thing
It had 128MB ram at the time.  I used XPostFacto, and version of BootX (I think).
I'm diggin' Linux, though, and I want to have a least one system running it.
Besides, I kind of like using the terminal sometimes.
it seems you have at least one system running on it
the terminal is your friend
Okay, it's time to test/setup the wireless.
I'm out.
the desktop man
the one with the plan
howdy
Howdy, nalioth!
you should always boot wiht the hardware you want to use installed
howzit goin?
you are speaking to a Robot
don't tease the bot, he doesnt like it
too many other folks have abused poor ol' ubotu
goin on vacation?
look in ##apple
back to cause more trouble?
Hi nalioth, how're you?
breezy is broken until oct 13. live with your decision
the next update or two should fix your problem
Wait - does that mean I've upgrade to Breezy?
i'm fine today. and you?
Fine.
Thanks for asking
What's a way to reveal that I'm using Breezy?
open a terminal, and type uname -a
Yes, but that simply tells me the kernel
Once you perform an apt-get dist-upgrade, do you need to inform BootX or Yaboot that you've changed the kernel?
on yaboot, you'll want to run 'sudo ybin' to set the new settings into nvram
i'm not sure on bootx (probably have to move the initrc and all that happy stuff back to the boot block)
Thanks
you old sneaky snake, where you been?
I haven't checked in in awhile.  How've you been?
you here?
Okay, I've go to go.  I'll check in tomorrow or the next day and stay longer.
howdy
Howdy
choose 'rescue' ?
what trouble do you have now? lol
Hi there.  Yes, it seems I'm always having trouble.  Must be due to my wanting a challenge, remember?
so what is your question?
I wanted to go the pure GUI-less route, so I tried to install Debian...
...but didn't get very far.  (Mac wouldn't 'see' my floppy.)  So now it's back to Ubuntu...
we have a 'server install', you know
I've never been able to get to the server installer prompt.
How do you do that again?
you can run BUM in the gui and turn off the gui altogether
at the install prompt, type 'server' <enter>
See, that's the problem.  Never get the install prompt.
then use bum to turn off your X
I guess I'll do that once I get installed.  But the problem is...
...I've rebooted after the bootloader stage, and...
...now I recieve this error about the tty...
you may need to install hoary and upgrade
I've tried that route.  Changed the sources from Hoary to Breezy, ran the dist-upgrade...
...then after rebooting had another error.
Someone here said it appeared to be a hardware error.
Hoary ran fine on my Mac, though.
I suppose I could just step back to Hoary.
if it works, and you're only gonna run CLI, hoary should be fine
Would Breezy improve upon this old horse (and Old World Powerbook G3)?  Any idea, nalioth?
Arghh!  Never should have tried to upgrade!  This put me back about a week...
i suspect hoary is as good as you will need on that old warhorse
Hey nalioth, once I have Hoary installed, can I easily install pure debian?
no
Are you just saying that because you don't want me migrating to debian?
hoary is way beyond any shipping version of debian
if you want a console only box, try netbsd
Even in CLI mode?
Now you're just trying to make my life difficult, nalioth!  LOL
I've seriously consider installing FreeBSD or Darwin on this old box.
Or OpenDarwin.
install hoary, use BUM to shut off your x loading and be happy
My main focus is on continuing my programming edumacation now, though, rather than installing Linux ever other day.
if you desire a cli linux, see above
I *will* be happy.  I dig this community enough to make me want to stick with Ubuntu, but I dig the purity of Debian.  Do you know what I mean?
hoary has a console program to do everything you could need
Yes, but Ubuntu's installer installs way more software than I want or need for CLI, and I haven't been able to install server only.
Waitaminute - aren't you using Debian, nalioth?
only the ubuntu branch
Good.  So how is Houston?
Well, thanks again, as always.  If i get this figured out I'll definitely put up a wiki this time.
still here after all the hurricanes
And I'll look into BUM.
Good
I just realized where I went wrong!
Good news - I input the wrong 'root=/dev/hda10' command in BootX.
welcome to breezy
So now it's completing the installation process...!
you can still use BUM to keep your X from starting
I'll do that.
So I'll complete the installation, and I'll let you know if anything goes wrong.
Somehow you always manage to keep me using Ubunut.
you got it (thanks to the hoary learning curve)
By the way, the new instructions for Old World Macs someone posted to the wiki is much clearer than the last: http://wiki.ubuntu.com/Installation/OldWorldMacs
wikis evolve
is that your next project? UbuntuPSP ?
Very funny.
I can barely manage an install on an old Powerbook.  You think it'd be advisable to even *attempt* an install on a PSP?
Besides, where am I going to get the bread for a PSP?
Did you know there was a Ubuntu-server download?  Why didn't you tell me?  I'm downloading the ISO now.
every ubuntu disk has a server install in it (no extra charge)
Yes, but since I can't access server during my Old World Mac installation process, downloading the server ISO may make the process possible.
well have fun (the ubuntu-server is bleeding edge)
When you boot into the Ubuntu installer from BootX, when exactly are you supposed to type 'server' (or 'custom')?
at the blinking 'boot' prompt
And since there is no blinking 'boot' prompt when you go from BootX?
you got me there
Strange; this announcement says Ubuntu 5.10 Server is the first release: http://lwn.net/Articles/156309/
i DID say it was bleeding edge stuff
install xubuntu-desktop
Hi.  Yeah, I've just installed Ubuntu Server (from the Ubuntu Server CD)!
xubuntu-desktop will give you a nice xfce4 desktop
I've been preferring fluxbox to xfce4; which direction would I go towards installing that?
sudo apt-get install fluxbox lbpager fbdesk fluxconf wmfrog
Thanks - how did you remember all of those?
remember all of what?  :
when you issue that command, it will install xorg and other GUI packages, also
How did you remember what to install?  (You listed 5 different things.)
c/p that whole line
Oh boy, that'll take up some space.  But probably not enough to fill 1.7GB, right?
I believe I will.
not at all
You're truly amazing.
Thanks, and make sure to keep in touch.  http://somethingthathappened.com
not really, just a common nerd
Before I do this, I'm going to research xubuntu some.
wiki.ubuntu.com/xubuntu
Already there, but thanks!
What's 'lbpager'?  You suggested installing it yesterday.
it's a pager for your fluxbox
You sure that's not 'bbpager'?
open a terminal and type 'apt-cache search fluxbox'
Thanks.  I'm just asking 'cuz I typed in the full line you gave me and it couldn't find lbpager.
you are using breezy right? with uni and multienabled?
I enabled uni, but prolly not multi.  Lemme check...
I don't currently have access to my Ubuntu machine's screen; how do I obtain it's IP address in order to log into it remotely.  The machine is on my home network.
you are in a classic catch-22
Uh oh.
See, I've just installed gdm and now my Mac's screen is dark when I reboot.
so ctrl-alt-f3, log in and type ifconfig
That's not doing it.  Still dark.  Hm...
ctrl-alt-f(1-6) should get you a text terminal
Here's a question I've had for a long time.
Whenever I install Ubuntu on this old Mac, the screen is unevenly divided into about 4 parts.
and how did you fix in on hoary?
This is resolved by selecting 'no video driver' in BootX....
However, by selecting that, I can no longer see the bootup process.
The only thing I can see, in fact...
...is a blank screen until I get to the wdm.  That's how it was with Hoary...
otw, you get 4x til you get to gdm?
But now, I'm not appearing to reach wdm.
One sec...
No - when I select 'no video driver', I get a blank (slightly glowing) screen until the wdm.
It's only when I do not select 'no video driver' that I get the uneven 4 images.
and you cant ctrl-alt-f3 to a text terminal?
No.  Here...
I've just taken off the 'no video driver' so that i can watch the bootup process, and...
...i can see that the last message is that it is starting up wdm, then quickly i catch a text login prompt before it goes dark.
i'm still not understanding why you cant hit ctrl-alt-f4 and find a text login screen
One thing: i know I can access login in the dark (that's how i just displayed wdm, as I had gdm installed before, which also was doing this0
Don't know either.  Perhaps xserver-xorg isn't configured properly?  (Just a guess.)  Unfortunatley, i can't my display to run any tests/commands.
you should be able to access a console login tho
If only i could ssh into the machine somehow...
Okay, in the dark I've entered 'sudo apt-get remove wdm gdm'
...and then my password...
So I'll reboot after this and see if I can get back to a quadrupled text prompt.
What command removes wdm (or any other package)?  'apt-get remove wdm'?
correct. use sudo
hello!
Hello
What's up, cowperson?
I've settled with not installing a GUI on my Breezy Mac
I may change my mind, however, once Xubuntu has a Ubuntu theme delivered.  Probably on the next release of Ubuntu.
sounds good. xubuntu didnt do it for ya, eh?
Well, no, not yet.  But I have hopes.
Ever use 'screen'?
all the time (got 4 screen sessions goin right now)
How would I copy and paste text?  Not findng anything n the manual...
i've heard that highligting copies and middle clicking pastes, but i dont c/p from screen sessins
Thanks, nalioth
Ever play Nethack?
way long ago
Just read about it.
Installing it now.
get 'hunt the wumpus' or 'wumpus' also
I've heard of wumpus.  Is it better?
it's even more mindless
lol
ifconfig
are you back causing more trouble?
Thank you
Yes, just shaking it all up
I've been going the GUI-less route, and it's working out well.  Learning to master vim!
Still loving ubuntu, and debian in general.
rock on, dude
Rock and roll oblivion!
What's your music, nalioth?
#ubuntu-offtopic please

ifconfig, ipconfig is for windows
if you like having 'ipconfig' you can always alias it
I forgot; haven't played with my settings in awhile
